\title{Four  manifolds with  harmonic Weyl tensor and postive Yamabe constant}


\author{Hai-Ping Fu}

\address{Department of Mathematics,  Nanchang University, Nanchang, P.
R. China 330031}



\email{mathfu@126.com}

\thanks{Supported in part by National Natural Science Foundations of China \#11261038 and \#11361041.}









\subjclass[2000]{Primary 53C21; Secondary 53C20}





\keywords{Einstein manifold,  self-dual, harmonic Weyl tensor , Yamabe constant}

\begin{abstract}
We refine Theorem A in \cite{G3}. As applications, we give some rigidity theorems on four-manifolds with harmonic Weyl tensor. In particular, these rigidity theorems are sharp for our conditions have the additional properties of being sharp. By this we mean that we can precisely characterize the case of equality. We reprove Theorems A and B in \cite{CGY} in some sense.
\end{abstract}

\maketitle

\section{Introduction and main results}
In \cite {F}, the author proved that a  $n$-manifold with harmonic curvature which satisfies the inequality for some
curvature functionals whose upper bound is controlled by  Yamabe constant is actually isometric to a quotient of the standard sphere and precisely
characterize the case of equality. The aim of this paper is to present some results in the subject of curvature pinching on four  manifolds with  harmonic Weyl tensor.

The sphere theorem for $\frac14$-pinched Riemannian manifolds, conjectured by H. Rauch
in 1951, is a  good example of the deep connections between the topology
and the geometry of Riemannian manifolds. After a large amount of research, now we know that the
answer is positive, due to the fundamental work of Klingenberg, Berger and Rauch
for the topological statement and the recent proof of the original conjecture by Brendle
and Schoen \cite{BS}, based on the results of B\"{o}hm and Wilking \cite{BW}.

Let $(M^n, g)$ be a $n$-dimensional Riemannian manifold. The
decomposition of the Riemannian curvature tensor $Rm$  into irreducible components yield
\begin{eqnarray*}
Rm=W+\frac{1}{n-2}\mathring{Ric}\circledwedge g+
\frac{R}{2n(n-1)}g\circledwedge g,
\end{eqnarray*}
where  $W$, $Ric$, $\mathring{Ric}=Ric-\frac{R}{n}g$ and $R$ denote the Weyl curvature tensor,  Ricci tensor,  trace-free Ricci tensor   and   scalar curvature, respectively. When the divergence of the Weyl curvature tensor  $W$ is vanishing, i.e., $\delta W=0$, $(M^n, g)$ is said to be a manifold with  harmonic Weyl tensor.

Now, since the work of Huisken \cite{Hu} and Margerin \cite{M}, we know that there exists a positive-dimensional constant
$C(n)$ such that if $|W+\frac{1}{n-2}\mathring{Ric}\circledwedge g|^2 < C(n)R^2(g)$, then $M^n$ is diffeomorphic to a quotient of the standard unit sphere. In particular, Margerin improved the constant in dimension four, and obtained the
optimal theorem in \cite{M}.

The common feature of all those results is to give topological information on a manifold
that carry a metric whose curvature satisfies a certain pinching at each point.
The question we raise here is whether one can characterize spherical space forms by means of integral
pinching conditions instead of pointwise ones.

Some results in this direction was obtained by Chang, Gursky and Yang \cite{CGY}, Gursky \cite{{G2},{G3}}, Hebey and Vaugon \cite{HV}, Bour and Carron \cite{BC}, and the author \cite{F}. Chang, Gursky and Yang proved that a  four-manifold which satisfies the inequality for some
curvature functionals is actually diffeomorphic to a quotient of the sphere and precisely
characterize the case of equality in \cite{CGY}. When the underlying four-manifold satisfies
certain topological conditions, Gursky gave a sharp lower bound for the self-dual Weyl functional and provided a precise characterization of
metrics which achieve the infimum in \cite{{G2},{G3}}.

In four-manifolds, the Weyl functional $\int |W_{g}|^2$  has long been an object of
interest to physicists. Suppose $M^4$ is a four-dimensional manifold. Then the Hodge
$\ast$-operator induces a splitting of the space of two-forms $\wedge^2=\wedge^2_{+}+\wedge^2_{-}$ into the
subspace of self-dual forms $\wedge^2_{+}$ and anti-self-dual forms $\wedge^2_{-}$. This splitting in
turn induces a decomposition of the Weyl curvature  into its self-dual and anti-self-dual components $W^{\pm}$. A four-manifold is said to be self-dual (resp., anti-self-dual) if $W^-=0$ (resp., $W^+$).  By
the Hirzebruch signature formula (see \cite{B}),

When (1.2) is replaced by (1.4) and (1.3) is replaced by (1.7), for four-manifolds with $\delta W^{+}=0$, M. Gursky proved the first of Theorem 1.2 and  Theorem 1.3. Theorems 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3 refine Theorem A in \cite{G3}.

For four-manifolds $M^4$ with harmonic Weyl tensor and  positive Yamabe constant $\mu([g])$ which is not locally conformally flat , the
 lower bound for $\mu([g])$ is given by i) if $M$ is anti-self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \int_M|W^{-}|^2$;  ii) if $M$ is self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \int_M|W^{+}|^2$;  iii) if $M$ is neither anti-self-dual nor self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \min\{\int_M|W^{-}|^2, \int_M|W^{+}|^2\}$. There exists   a compact positive Einstein manifold $(M^4, g)$ which is either K\"{a}hler, or the quotient of a K\"{a}hler manifold by a free, isometric,
anti-holomorphic involution such that the Yamabe constant $\mu^2([g])$ of $(M^4, g)$ is equal to $32\pi^2(2\chi(M^4)+3\sigma(M^4))$.
\end{remark}

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int_{M}|W_{g}^{+}|^{2}=\frac{16}{3}\pi^{2}(2\chi(M^{4})+3\sigma(M^{4}))." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mi>M</mi></msub><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msubsup><mi>W</mi><mi>g</mi><mo>+</mo></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>16</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>π</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>M</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>M</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
In fact, by Theorem 1.2 and (1.3), we have $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}=\frac 16\mu^2([g])= 16\int_M \sigma_2(A)$. Hence the equalities in (1.6) hold.

When (1.2) is replaced by (1.4) and (1.3) is replaced by (1.7), for four-manifolds with $\delta W^{+}=0$, M. Gursky proved the first of Theorem 1.2 and  Theorem 1.3. Theorems 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3 refine Theorem A in \cite{G3}.

For four-manifolds $M^4$ with harmonic Weyl tensor and  positive Yamabe constant $\mu([g])$ which is not locally conformally flat , the
 lower bound for $\mu([g])$ is given by i) if $M$ is anti-self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \int_M|W^{-}|^2$;  ii) if $M$ is self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \int_M|W^{+}|^2$;  iii) if $M$ is neither anti-self-dual nor self-dual, $\mu^2([g])\leq 6 \min\{\int_M|W^{-}|^2, \int_M|W^{+}|^2\}$. There exists   a compact positive Einstein manifold $(M^4, g)$ which is either K\"{a}hler, or the quotient of a K\"{a}hler manifold by a free, isometric,
anti-holomorphic involution such that the Yamabe constant $\mu^2([g])$ of $(M^4, g)$ is equal to $32\pi^2(2\chi(M^4)+3\sigma(M^4))$.
\end{remark}

\begin{proof}[{\bf Proof of Theorem
1.2}]
By Theorem 1.1, either $(M^4, g)$ is anti-self-dual (resp., self-dual), or
$\int_{M}|W_g^{\pm}|^{2}\geq\frac 16\mu^2([g])$.  The equality hold in (1.2) imply that there exists a conformally metric $\tilde{g}$ of $g$ such that $\int_{M}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\pm}|^{2}=\int_{M}|W_{g}^{\pm}|^{2}=\frac 16\int_{M}R_{\tilde{g}}^{2}$. By Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3},  we get $R_{\tilde{g}}\equiv \sqrt{6}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\pm}|$ . Since it follows by Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3} that  the sign of $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{6}|W_{{g}}^{\pm}|$ is a conformal invariant , $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{6}|W_{{g}}^{\pm}|=0$. From (2.4), by the maximum principle we get $|W^{\pm}|$ is constant, thus $\nabla W^{\pm}=0$. Then equality holds in (2.3) at each point
of $M$, and thus $W^{\pm}$ has exactly two distinct eigenvalues at each point.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof}[{\bf Proof of Theorem
1.5}]
It is easy to see from (1.8) that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$ or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$. By Theorem 1.2, $W^{+}=0$ or $W^{-}=0$.  Then $g$ is both Einstein and half conformally flat. By the classification theorem
of Hitchin (see \cite{B}), $(M^4, g)$ is isometric to either a quotient of $\mathbb{S}^4$ with the round metric or
$\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric. Since we are assuming that is not locally conformal flat, $(M^4, g)$ is $\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric.
\end{proof}

The above equality implies that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$ or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$. By Theorem 1.2, we get $W_g^{+}=0$ or $W_g^{-}=0$.
Thus $\int_{M}|W_g^{\pm}|^{2}=\frac 16\mu^2([g])$, by Theorem 1.2, $|W_g^{\pm}|$ is constant. On the other hand, $g$ is conformally
Einstein such that $\int_{M}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\pm}|^{2}=\int_{M}|W_{g}^{\pm}|^{2}=\frac 16\int_{M}R_{\tilde{g}}^{2}$. By Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3},  we get $R_{\tilde{g}}\equiv \sqrt{6}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\pm}|$ . Since it follows by Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3} that  the sign of $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{6}|W_{{g}}^{\pm}|$ is a conformal invariant , $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{6}|W_{{g}}^{\pm}|=0$. Hence $g$ has constant scalar curvature.We get that $g$ is Einstein from the proof of Obata Theorem (see \cite{LP}).  By Theorem 1.5, $(M^4, g)$ is $\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric.
\end{proof}

\begin{proof}[{\bf Proof of Theorem
1.13}]Case 1. $\mathring{Ric}=0$, i.e., $M$ is Einstein. It is easy to see from (1.11) that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$, $\int_{M}|W_g^{\pm}|^{2}=\frac 16\mu^2([g])$  or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$.

When $\int_{M}|W_g^{\pm}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$, by Theorem 1.1, we have $W^{\pm}=0$.
Then $g$ is both Einstein and half conformally flat. By the classification theorem
of Hitchin, $(M^4, g)$ is isometric to either $\mathbb{S}^4$ with the round metric or
$\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric. Since we are assuming that is not locally conformal flat, $(M^4, g)$ is $\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric. Since $\mathbb{CP}^2$ is Einstein, (1.11) implies that $\int_{M}|W_g^{\mp}|^{2}=\frac 13\mu^2([g])$. Then there exists a conformally metric $\tilde{g}$ of $g$ such that $\int_{M}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\mp}|^{2}=\int_{M}|W_{g}^{\mp}|^{2}=\frac 13\int_{M}R_{\tilde{g}}^{2}$. By Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3},  we get $R_{\tilde{g}}\equiv \sqrt{3}|W_{\tilde{g}}^{\mp}|$ . Since it follows by Proposition 3.2 in \cite{G3} that  the sign of $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{3}|W_{{g}}^{\mp}|$ is a conformal invariant , $R_{{g}}-\sqrt{3}|W_{{g}}^{\mp}|=0$. From (2.4), by the maximum principle we get $W^{\mp}=0$. Hence $\mathbb{CP}^2$ is locally conformal flat. Contradiction.

When $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}=\frac 16\mu^2([g])$, by Theorem 1.2, $\nabla W^{+}=0$ and $W^{+}$ has exactly two distinct eigenvalues at each point. Since $M$ is Einstein, it follows from Theorem 2 of \cite{D} that  $(M^4, g)$ is an Einstein manifold
which is either K\"{a}hler, or the quotient of a K\"{a}hler manifold by a free, isometric,
anti-holomorphic involution.


Case 2. $\mathring{Ric}\neq0$. It is easy to see from (1.11) that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$ or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$.

When $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, we have $W^{+}=0$, i.e., $M$ is anti-self-dual.

When  $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, $ W^{-}=0$. Since $\delta W=0$, by Proposition 7 in \cite{D}, we get $M$ is confomally flat. Hence $\int_M|\mathring{Ric}|^2=\frac {1}{12}\mu^2([g])$
By Theorem 1.15 in \cite{FX}, (1.11) implies that $(M^4, g)$ is 4) or 5).
\end{proof}

When $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, we have $W^{+}=0$, i.e., $M$ is anti-self-dual.

When  $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, $ W^{-}=0$. Since $\delta W=0$, by Proposition 7 in \cite{D}, we get $M$ is confomally flat. Hence $\int_M|\mathring{Ric}|^2<\frac {1}{12}\mu^2([g])$

which is either K\"{a}hler, or the quotient of a K\"{a}hler manifold by a free, isometric,
anti-holomorphic involution.

\begin{proof}[{\bf Proof of Theorem
1.14}]Case 1. $\mathring{Ric}=0$, i.e., $M$ is Einstein. It is easy to see from (1.12) that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$ or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$.
By Theorem 1.1, we have $W^{+}=0$ or $W^{-}=0$.
 By the classification theorem
of Hitchin, $(M^4, g)$ is isometric to either a quotient of $\mathbb{S}^4$ with the round metric or
$\mathbb{CP}^2$ with the Fubini-Study metric.


Case 2. $\mathring{Ric}\neq0$. It is easy to see from (1.12) that $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$ or $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$.

When $\int_{M}|W_g^{+}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, we have $W^{+}=0$, i.e., $M$ is anti-self-dual.

When  $\int_{M}|W_g^{-}|^{2}<\frac 16\mu^2([g])$,  by Theorem 1.1, $ W^{-}=0$. Since $\delta W=0$, by Proposition 7 in \cite{D}, we get $M$ is confomally flat. Hence $\int_M|\mathring{Ric}|^2<\frac {1}{12}\mu^2([g])$
By Theorem 1.13 in \cite{FX}, (1.12) implies that $(M^4, g)$ is a quotient of the round $\mathbb{S}^4$. Contradiction.
\end{proof}
